origination.corpname: Fund for the Advancement of Education (U.S.)

physdesc.extent: 83 boxes - 82 letter document containers and 1 half-legal document container

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

The Fund for Adult Education (FAE) and The Fund for the Advancement of Education (TFAE) were established by the Ford Foundation in 1951 as semi-autonomous funds to obtain large-scale results quickly and to help the Ford Foundation avoid violating federal laws which forbade tax-exempt foundations from accumulating "unreasonable" surpluses.

The Fund for Adult Education played a major role in the early development of public television stations and programming with grants totaling more than $11 million. A second major effort of FAE was to develop a series of study-discussion programs as a method of bringing adults together with trained program leaders to discuss such topics as American History, the arts, and world affairs and to create a body of materials that could be published and used nationwide. FAE's final project was "Education for Public Responsibility." FAE made grants of $1.5 million to universities and professional organizations for programs, conferences, and fellowships to prepare young and middle level professionals to face contemporary problems and issues. FAE was terminated in 1961.

The Fund for the Advancement of Education supported new and experimental programs at all levels of formal education. The five areas to which TFAE focused its resources were: the equalization of educational opportunity; improvements in curricula; clarification of the functions of educational institutions; improvement of educational management and financing; and the improvement of teaching. TFAE operated for over a decade. It ceased funding new projects in the late 1960s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains publications originally held in the Ford Foundation's library and archives. The subject matter of the materials reflects the work of the Foundation, the Fund for Adult Education, and the Fund for the Advancement of Education.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged into four series:
4. The Fund for the Advancement of Education (TFAE) Publications

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2013 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as part of Accession 2013:005.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation Staff Publications

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged loosely alphabetically by last name of author. Ford Foundation staff author name is noted on each book's spine. "Staff:" in the folder title typically indicates there are multiple authors. The author's name after the colon denotes the Ford Foundation staff member(s) whose writing is included in the collaborative work.
